sect2.title: Introduction
sect2.para: The Spring Modules XT Ajax Framework is based on the following fundamental concepts:

listitem.para: Events
Handlers
Actions
Components
Responses

sect2.para: They work together in a simple processing flow:

listitem.para: Web pages fire events using standard JavaScript events.
Each event causes an Ajax request that is processed by simple Java objects acting as server side handlers.
The handler process the event creating actions.
Each action may render one or more HTML components in the page.
At the end, actions are canalised into an Ajax response sent back to the web page.

sect2.para: We'll take a more detailed look to each of the concepts above in the next section.

sect3.title: Ajax Events
sect3.para: In Spring Modules XT Ajax framework you can raise events from your web pages as standard JavaScript events, and handle them server side. There are actually the following types of Ajax events:

listitem.para: Action events, a generic event type directly handled by configured handlers without calling any Spring MVC controller.
Submit events, a special type of event handled by configured handlers after executing any Spring MVC controller.

sect3.title: Ajax Handlers
sect3.para: The Ajax handler is the server side component to be implemented for managing Ajax events. This is the base interface of an Ajax handler:

listitem.para: public boolean supports(AjaxEvent event) : Check if ''this'' handler supports (can handle) the given, generic, AjaxEvent
public AjaxResponse handle(AjaxEvent event) : Handle the given, generic, AjaxEvent (if supported) and returns an appropriate AjaxResponse (see Ajax Response).

You've seen how to fire events from web pages, and how to handle them through AjaxHandlers. The next step is how to associate events with handlers.

sect4.title: Associating events with handlers
sect4.para: Once defined your events and implemented your handlers, you need to associate them.

For security reason, web pages events and ajax handlers are not automatically associated, nor can be globally associated. If it were so, malicious users could hack your JavaScript events and execute unwanted events.

So, events and handlers are associated per page path, that is, you have to configure every handler to manage events fired by a pre-determined, restricted, set of pages. Specifically, you can configure an handler to manage events fired by a specific, single, web page, or by web pages defined with Ant style pattern matching. An example is worth thousand words:

As you can notice, handlers are configured into the Spring application context, via a standard bean configuration. Specifically, they are configured in the AjaxInterceptor bean. The first ''prop'' entry associate the handler with an Ant style pattern, while others associate handlers with single pages. Doing so, you can also ''merge'' handlers, applying more handlers to the same group of pages. When more handlers apply for the same event, the one configured for matching the longest path wins.

sect3.title: Ajax Actions
sect3.para: Ajax actions are created by handlers and have effect on the client. This is the base interface for implementing an Ajax action:

listitem.para: public String execute() : Execute the action, optionally returning a string representing the action result.

sect3.para: Actions can do various things, depending on the concrete implementation: most of the time they render HTML components.

sect3.title: Components
sect3.para: AjaxActions can render HTML components implementing this interface:

Each component renders itself through the render() method, returning a string representation of the HTML rendering. So, the execute() method of actions rendering components returns the rendering of all associated components. The association between actions and components depends on the concrete action implementation: however, most of the time it is at action construction. Here is a code snippet:

sect3.title: Ajax Response
sect3.para: AjaxResponse objects finally carry actions to clients. This is the base interface:

listitem.para: public void addAction(T action) : Add an action to send to the client.
public String getResponse() : Return the current response, as resulted from actions currently contained.

sect3.para: Once constructed and filled with actions, you'll have to simply return your Ajax response from your handler method.
